An **owlbear**, Y, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a large, [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivorous "Carnivorous") [apelike creature](/wiki/Apelike_creature "Apelike creature") that is [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong") and can be seen via [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision").

An owlbear possesses two claw attacks and a [grabbing attack](/wiki/Grabbing_attack "Grabbing attack") that holds [you](/wiki/You "You") in place and crushes you each turn.

A few [special messages](#Messages) generated by some [traps](/wiki/Trap "Trap") are associated with owlbears.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Messages](#Messages)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly generated owlbears are always created hostile.

Owlbears appear among the random Y that make up the second [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class") for [Healers](/wiki/Healer "Healer") and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the [Healer quest](/wiki/Healer_quest "Healer quest").

On the goal level of the [Wizard quest](/wiki/Wizard_quest "Wizard quest"), a peaceful [sleeping](/wiki/Sleeping "Sleeping") owlbear is placed in the top right cell of the [Dark One](/wiki/Dark_One "Dark One")'s dungeon at level creation.

## Strategy

Owlbears represent one of the many early-game threats that require players to be cautious about approaching monsters in combat: they can move at the same speed as a character that is unburdened and does not have a source of speed, and their grabbing attack can grind away HP while trapping them in place for other hostile monsters to attack freely. [Greased](/wiki/Greased "Greased") outer [body armor](/wiki/Body_armor "Body armor") or a non-cursed [oilskin cloak](/wiki/Oilskin_cloak "Oilskin cloak") can prevent an owlbear from getting a hold of a character at all.

[Ranged attacks](/wiki/Ranged_attack "Ranged attack"), including [spells](/wiki/Spell "Spell") and [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand"), can kill an owlbear at a safe distance or weaken it enough for your character to finish off in melee. If caught in the owlbear's grasp, you can [teleport](/wiki/Teleport "Teleport") yourself free or [scare](/wiki/Scare "Scare") the owlbear into letting you go, e.g. by using a tool to scare it or engraving [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth") with an applicable wand; scaring the owlbear has the additional boon of keeping it away from you for at least a few turns. Inflicting [sleep](/wiki/Sleep "Sleep") or [paralysis](/wiki/Paralysis "Paralysis") on the owlbear has a chance of making it release you, but this is unreliable since the owlbear may be awakened if you are still in its grasp and attempt to move away.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

Once you can reliably take down owlbears, their [corpses](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") are quite filling and can also be left for any meat-eating pets, with a non-rotten owlbear [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") providing nutrition comparable to a [food ration](/wiki/Food_ration "Food ration").

## History

The owlbear first appears in Hack for PDP-11, a variant of [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"), and is included in the initial bestiary for [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0").

From Hack for PDP-11 to [NetHack 2.3e](/wiki/NetHack_2.3e "NetHack 2.3e"), the owlbear uses the o glyph. In [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"), the various new and returning [orcs](/wiki/Orc_\(monster_class\) "Orc (monster class)") are moved to the o glyph; the owlbear is moved to the [giant humanoid](/wiki/Giant_humanoid "Giant humanoid") [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class") at H. In [NetHack 3.1.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.0 "NetHack 3.1.0"), owlbears are reclassified as apelike creatures and moved to their current glyph.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Owlbear](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search/Owlbear "wikipedia:Special:Search/Owlbear")***

The owlbear (also written as "owl bear") is one of many *NetHack* creatures that comes from *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, first appearing in the 1975 *Greyhawk* supplement for the original release. The owlbear and several other creatures in particular, such as the [rust monster](/wiki/Rust_monster "Rust monster"), were based on dime-store plastic toys that were used by Gary Gygax and other play-testers as monster figures, with their appearances based directly on the toys.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) The owlbear has since appeared in every subsequent edition of the game, as well as several other fantasy role-playing games, video games and fantasy media, and is widely considered one of the franchise's most memorable monsters.

As the name suggests, the owlbear is depicted as a cross between a bear and a giant owl that stands upright on two legs and has dark fur, feathers, and a yellow or ivory beak. It is a carnivorous creature known for aggression and ferocity, and attacks by using its beak, claws and grappling bear-like "hugs". Their in-universe origin is unclear, though the various *Monster Manual* editions indicate that it is believed to be the product of a wizard's experiments; in the 5th edition, some elves claim that owlbears have existed for millennia, while older fey say that they have always existed in the Feywild.

Owlbears live in temperate climes and forested areas, establishing their lairs in tangled woods, near-surface caves, within large hollow trees and stumps, and among ruins. Their favored hunting grounds are usually dense wooded areas that they were familiar with; they clawed at certain trees to both mark territory and sharpen their claws. Owlbear lairs often contain up to six eggs and/or six young owlbears; they are frequent hunters and usually appear alone, in mated pairs with a territory of 1​-​2 square miles, or in packs that consist of up to five or even eight owlbears.

## Messages

- The owlbear snarls.

  You [chatted](/wiki/Chat "Chat") to an owlbear.

- You hear the roaring of an angry bear!

  An unseen owlbear was caught in a [bear trap](/wiki/Bear_trap "Bear trap").

- You hear the roaring of a confused bear!

  An unseen owlbear was caught in a [web](/wiki/Web "Web").

- You howl in anger!

  You walked into a bear trap while polymorphed into an owlbear.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), owlbears [hit as a +1 weapon](/wiki/Hits_creatures_as_%2Bx_weapon "Hits creatures as +x weapon").

The [Necromancer quest](/wiki/Necromancer_quest "Necromancer quest") has a peaceful owlbear on the goal level, which is a duplicate of the Wizard quest's goal level: the owlbear occupies the same exact prison cell in the top right of the level.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), owlbears are [oviparous](/wiki/Oviparous "Oviparous"): owlbear eggs can hatch into [baby owlbears](/wiki/Baby_owlbear "Baby owlbear"), which in turn can [grow up](/wiki/Grow_up "Grow up") into adult owlbears. Owlbears also have their first claw attack replaced with a bite attack.

The [owlbear nest](/index.php?title=Owlbear_nest\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Owlbear nest (page does not exist)") is a [special room](/index.php?title=Special_room_\(EvilHack\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Special room (EvilHack) (page does not exist)") that contains several owlbear eggs and sleeping baby owlbears, along with an adult owlbear.

## Encyclopedia entry

Owlbears are probably the crossbreed creation of a demented  
wizard; given the lethal nature of this creation, it is quite  
likely the wizard who created them is no longer alive. As  
the name might already suggest, owlbears are a cross between  
a giant owl and a bear. They are covered with fur and  
feathers.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/hack.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1530](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/hack.c#L1530)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) ["Owlbears, Rust Monsters and Bulettes, Oh My!" - Tony DiTerlizzi](https://diterlizzi.com/essay/owlbears-rust-monsters-and-bulettes-oh-my/)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
html:
Owlbear

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
Y owlbear
Difficulty 7
Attacks Claw 1d6, Claw 1d6, Hug 2d8
Y owlbear
Difficulty 7
Attacks

Claw 1d6, Claw 1d6, Hug 2d8

Base level 5
Base experience 94
Speed 12
Base AC 5
Base MR 0
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 3 (Rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 1700
Nutritional value 700
Size Large
Resistances None
Resistances conveyed None

An owlbear:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is an animal.
  • is carnivorous.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • is nasty.
  • is strong.
  • can be seen through infravision.
Reference monst.c#line1929

An owlbear, Y, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. It is a large, carnivorous apelike creature that is strong and can be seen via infravision.

An owlbear possesses two claw attacks and a grabbing attack that holds you in place and crushes you each turn.

A few special messages generated by some traps are associated with owlbears.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Messages
  • 6 Variants
    • 6.1 SLASH'EM
    • 6.2 EvilHack
  • 7 Encyclopedia entry
  • 8 References

Generation

Randomly generated owlbears are always created hostile.

Owlbears appear among the random Y that make up the second quest monster class for Healers and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the Healer quest.

On the goal level of the Wizard quest, a peaceful sleeping owlbear is placed in the top right cell of the Dark One's dungeon at level creation.

Strategy

Owlbears represent one of the many early-game threats that require players to be cautious about approaching monsters in combat: they can move at the same speed as a character that is unburdened and does not have a source of speed, and their grabbing attack can grind away HP while trapping them in place for other hostile monsters to attack freely. Greased outer body armor or a non-cursed oilskin cloak can prevent an owlbear from getting a hold of a character at all.

Ranged attacks, including spells and wands, can kill an owlbear at a safe distance or weaken it enough for your character to finish off in melee. If caught in the owlbear's grasp, you can teleport yourself free or scare the owlbear into letting you go, e.g. by using a tool to scare it or engraving Elbereth with an applicable wand; scaring the owlbear has the additional boon of keeping it away from you for at least a few turns. Inflicting sleep or paralysis on the owlbear has a chance of making it release you, but this is unreliable since the owlbear may be awakened if you are still in its grasp and attempt to move away.[1]

Once you can reliably take down owlbears, their corpses are quite filling and can also be left for any meat-eating pets, with a non-rotten owlbear corpse providing nutrition comparable to a food ration.

History

The owlbear first appears in Hack for PDP-11, a variant of Jay Fenlason's Hack, and is included in the initial bestiary for Hack 1.0.

From Hack for PDP-11 to NetHack 2.3e, the owlbear uses the o glyph. In NetHack 3.0.0, the various new and returning orcs are moved to the o glyph; the owlbear is moved to the giant humanoid monster class at H. In NetHack 3.1.0, owlbears are reclassified as apelike creatures and moved to their current glyph.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Owlbear

The owlbear (also written as "owl bear") is one of many NetHack creatures that comes from Dungeons & Dragons, first appearing in the 1975 Greyhawk supplement for the original release. The owlbear and several other creatures in particular, such as the rust monster, were based on dime-store plastic toys that were used by Gary Gygax and other play-testers as monster figures, with their appearances based directly on the toys.[2] The owlbear has since appeared in every subsequent edition of the game, as well as several other fantasy role-playing games, video games and fantasy media, and is widely considered one of the franchise's most memorable monsters.

As the name suggests, the owlbear is depicted as a cross between a bear and a giant owl that stands upright on two legs and has dark fur, feathers, and a yellow or ivory beak. It is a carnivorous creature known for aggression and ferocity, and attacks by using its beak, claws and grappling bear-like "hugs". Their in-universe origin is unclear, though the various Monster Manual editions indicate that it is believed to be the product of a wizard's experiments; in the 5th edition, some elves claim that owlbears have existed for millennia, while older fey say that they have always existed in the Feywild.

Owlbears live in temperate climes and forested areas, establishing their lairs in tangled woods, near-surface caves, within large hollow trees and stumps, and among ruins. Their favored hunting grounds are usually dense wooded areas that they were familiar with; they clawed at certain trees to both mark territory and sharpen their claws. Owlbear lairs often contain up to six eggs and/or six young owlbears; they are frequent hunters and usually appear alone, in mated pairs with a territory of 1​-​2 square miles, or in packs that consist of up to five or even eight owlbears.

Messages

The owlbear snarls.
You chatted to an owlbear.
You hear the roaring of an angry bear!
An unseen owlbear was caught in a bear trap.
You hear the roaring of a confused bear!
An unseen owlbear was caught in a web.
You howl in anger!
You walked into a bear trap while polymorphed into an owlbear.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, owlbears hit as a +1 weapon.

The Necromancer quest has a peaceful owlbear on the goal level, which is a duplicate of the Wizard quest's goal level: the owlbear occupies the same exact prison cell in the top right of the level.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, owlbears are oviparous: owlbear eggs can hatch into baby owlbears, which in turn can grow up into adult owlbears. Owlbears also have their first claw attack replaced with a bite attack.

The owlbear nest is a special room that contains several owlbear eggs and sleeping baby owlbears, along with an adult owlbear.

Encyclopedia entry

Owlbears are probably the crossbreed creation of a demented
wizard; given the lethal nature of this creation, it is quite
likely the wizard who created them is no longer alive. As
the name might already suggest, owlbears are a cross between
a giant owl and a bear. They are covered with fur and
feathers.


References

  1. ↑ src/hack.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1530
  2. ↑ "Owlbears, Rust Monsters and Bulettes, Oh My!" - Tony DiTerlizzi

An '''owlbear''', {{monsym|owlbear}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is a large, [[carnivorous]] [[apelike creature]] that is [[strong]] and can be seen via [[infravision]].

An owlbear possesses two claw attacks and a [[grabbing attack]] that holds [[you]] in place and crushes you each turn.

A few [[#Messages|special messages]] generated by some [[trap]]s are associated with owlbears.

==Generation==
Randomly generated owlbears are always created hostile.

Owlbears appear among the random {{white|Y}} that make up the second [[quest]] [[monster class]] for [[Healer]]s and make up {{frac|6|175}} of the monsters randomly generated on the [[Healer quest]].

On the goal level of the [[Wizard quest]], a peaceful [[sleeping]] owlbear is placed in the top right cell of the [[Dark One]]'s dungeon at level creation.

==Strategy==
Owlbears represent one of the many early-game threats that require players to be cautious about approaching monsters in combat: they can move at the same speed as a character that is unburdened and does not have a source of speed, and their grabbing attack can grind away HP while trapping them in place for other hostile monsters to attack freely. [[Greased]] outer [[body armor]] or a non-cursed [[oilskin cloak]] can prevent an owlbear from getting a hold of a character at all.

[[Ranged attack]]s, including [[spell]]s and [[wand]]s, can kill an owlbear at a safe distance or weaken it enough for your character to finish off in melee. If caught in the owlbear's grasp, you can [[teleport]] yourself free or [[scare]] the owlbear into letting you go, e.g. by using a tool to scare it or engraving [[Elbereth]] with an applicable wand; scaring the owlbear has the additional boon of keeping it away from you for at least a few turns. Inflicting [[sleep]] or [[paralysis]] on the owlbear has a chance of making it release you, but this is unreliable since the owlbear may be awakened if you are still in its grasp and attempt to move away.{{refsrc|src/hack.c|1530|nethack=3.6.7}}

Once you can reliably take down owlbears, their [[corpse]]s are quite filling and can also be left for any meat-eating pets, with a non-rotten owlbear [[corpse]] providing nutrition comparable to a [[food ration]].

==History==
The owlbear first appears in Hack for PDP-11, a variant of [[Jay Fenlason's Hack]], and is included in the initial bestiary for [[Hack 1.0]].

From Hack for PDP-11 to [[NetHack 2.3e]], the owlbear uses the {{white|o}} glyph. In [[NetHack 3.0.0]], the various new and returning [[Orc (monster class)|orcs]] are moved to the {{white|o}} glyph; the owlbear is moved to the [[giant humanoid]] [[monster class]] at {{brown|H}}. In [[NetHack 3.1.0]], owlbears are reclassified as apelike creatures and moved to their current glyph.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia}}
The owlbear (also written as "owl bear") is one of many ''NetHack'' creatures that comes from ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'', first appearing in the 1975 ''Greyhawk'' supplement for the original release. The owlbear and several other creatures in particular, such as the [[rust monster]], were based on dime-store plastic toys that were used by Gary Gygax and other play-testers as monster figures, with their appearances based directly on the toys.<ref>[https://diterlizzi.com/essay/owlbears-rust-monsters-and-bulettes-oh-my/ "Owlbears, Rust Monsters and Bulettes, Oh My!" - Tony DiTerlizzi]</ref> The owlbear has since appeared in every subsequent edition of the game, as well as several other fantasy role-playing games, video games and fantasy media, and is widely considered one of the franchise's most memorable monsters.

As the name suggests, the owlbear is depicted as a cross between a bear and a giant owl that stands upright on two legs and has dark fur, feathers, and a yellow or ivory beak. It is a carnivorous creature known for aggression and ferocity, and attacks by using its beak, claws and grappling bear-like "hugs". Their in-universe origin is unclear, though the various ''Monster Manual'' editions indicate that it is believed to be the product of a wizard's experiments; in the 5th edition, some elves claim that owlbears have existed for millennia, while older fey say that they have always existed in the Feywild.

Owlbears live in temperate climes and forested areas, establishing their lairs in tangled woods, near-surface caves, within large hollow trees and stumps, and among ruins. Their favored hunting grounds are usually dense wooded areas that they were familiar with; they clawed at certain trees to both mark territory and sharpen their claws. Owlbear lairs often contain up to six eggs and/or six young owlbears; they are frequent hunters and usually appear alone, in mated pairs with a territory of 1​-​2 square miles, or in packs that consist of up to five or even eight owlbears.

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], owlbears [[Hits creatures as +x weapon|hit as a +1 weapon]].

The [[Necromancer quest]] has a peaceful owlbear on the goal level, which is a duplicate of the Wizard quest's goal level: the owlbear occupies the same exact prison cell in the top right of the level.

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], owlbears are [[oviparous]]: owlbear eggs can hatch into [[baby owlbear]]s, which in turn can [[grow up]] into adult owlbears. Owlbears also have their first claw attack replaced with a bite attack.

The [[owlbear nest]] is a [[Special room (EvilHack)|special room]] that contains several owlbear eggs and sleeping baby owlbears, along with an adult owlbear.
